meeting_annotations.speaker: Lisa Osborne
meeting_annotations.transcript: So we've mammals have evolved to have a microbiota. We take advantage of the signals that they provide. Um, they like building on what Corinne said about fiber, we don't have enzymes to break them down. We rely on the microbiota to do that. So on the evolutionary time scale of us of mammals, we've responded to the need to have these or we've lost if we ever had them, the ability to make enzymes that degrade fiber or lactase. So we've had genetic changes in response to being in contact with these things. But if the microbes can just evolve quicker, is that still coevolution? There you're responding to environmental changes that we introduce to them, but they have to be within us.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Corinne Maurice
meeting_annotations.transcript: And I think that that there also has to be a benefit for us. I mean, the whole term of like coevolution implies that the two players are involved. If if if only one adapts, but the other one doesn't get any benefit from it, this is just this is just a symbiosis, which is an interaction between two members. So I would go with the idea that either both need to benefit or one benefits to the expense of the other because it doesn't have to be a positive coevolution, but definitely both players or or all the players involved have to have some kind of like response or change to the evolution or or change in the other one. Like it it it has to be everyone involved, at least according to me.
